Title: the robotic manipulation

Scene: The apartment. A robotic arm is extracting some Chinese takeaway from a bag controlled by Howard.
Howard’s bedroom. Howard is being massaged by the robot hand.
Penny’s car. Amy is now in the back seat.
Howard: And now the kung pao chicken.
And finally, my moo shu pork.
Ah, there you have it, gentlemen. Our entire dinner unpacked by robot.
Why?
That, dear lady, is the Wolowitz Programmable Hand, designed for extravehicular repairs on the International Space Station.
Ask me to pass the soy sauce.
Mostly with Asian and Jewish astronauts.
Coming up. (Starts typing rapidly)
Just wait.
Okay, here we go. Passing the soy sauce. Put out your hand.
Hey, Sheldon?
No, not peace. Hang on.
You kidding? They still think it’s in a secure locker at JPL.
Borrowed. The trick is to carry it out to your car like you own it.
Raj and I entered Sheldon’s information on a dating site, and it spit out Amy Farrah Fowler.
Or, as we call them, Shamy.
I’m guessing that future historians will condemn us for not taking this opportunity to kill Sheldon.
Oh, God, that feels so good. Yeah, that’s the spot. Oh, baby.
I’ll eat later. I’m busy! Oh, yeah. Just like a real hand. Hmm.
Yes.
Yes. Now, help me!
Not funny, Leonard.
Please, before my mother walks in, just get this off me!
No, no! Don’t touch, the program is paused.
No, no! I loaded the wrong program. The hand thinks it’s holding a screwdriver in outer space. If you continue the program, it’s gonna start twisting.
What? No saws! One circumcision was enough.
Okay, I can’t believe this needs to be said out loud. No pulling, no saws, no torches.
I…
That’s great, Mom, thanks!
Don’t come up here!
Yes, but that’s not the point! Get me out of here.
Don’t tug. No tugging.
I slipped and fell.
It’s a robot arm.
I only built the arm.
Can you please just help me?
You think you could be a little more discreet?
But it’s frozen.
No, you see, it’s more complicated than that. (Nurse switches off computer) No, wait! (The hand lets go) Winnie the Pooh is out of the honey tree.
Leonard: I don’t think that’s going to happen, Sheldon.
Wait a minute– a child? You never see this girl. You just e-mail and text and Twitter. Now you’re considering having a baby?
I’d suggest a lubricant, but I have a feeling you fell on some of that as well.
You do what you want, I’m not touching another man’s honey tree.
Well, then what do you want us to do?
Excuse me, could you help us out?
Uh, it’s what controls the arm.
Yeah, yeah, great. Howard, uh, slow down. What do you mean it happened again?
Raj: You know, there’s something I’ve always wondered about Aquaman.
What would a toilet look like in Atlantis? How would you flush it? And when you did flush it, where would the poop go?
You slipped and fell into a robot hand?
Really? A robot hand’s got a death grip on your junk, dude. That’s funny, ask anyone.
A-All right, um, how about this. When, when Winnie the Pooh got his head stuck in the honey tree, his friends all grabbed onto him and pulled and pulled.
All right, uh, forget pulling. How about we get an electric saw and cut it off?
Right now, all I can think about is cookies and Hawaiian Punch.
Next time, take your own advice.
Now can we have cookies and Hawaiian Punch?
Sheldon: Impressive, but we must be cautious.
Today, it’s a Chinese food retrieval robot. Tomorrow, it travels back in time and tries to kill Sarah Connor.
No one ever does. That’s why it happens.
You realize, Penny, that the technology that went into this arm will one day make unskilled food servers such as yourself obsolete.
I thought you broke up with her. Why is she here?
I wouldn’t say amazing. At best, it’s a modest leap forward from the basic technology that gave us Country Bear Jamboree.
Yes? (Howard types. The hand puts up two fingers to Sheldon.) Peace?
She’s not my girlfriend.
She’s not my girlfriend.
She’s not my girlfriend.
All right, everyone pay attention. Yes, I have a friend named Amy Farrah Fowler. Yes, she is female. Yes, we communicate on a daily basis, but no, she is not my girlfriend.
Well, my work in physics, her work in neurobiology, and most recently, the possibility of our having a child together.

Amy pointed out that between the two of us, our genetic material has the potential of producing the first in a line of intellectually superior, benign overlords to guide humanity to a brighter tomorrow.
Yes, Penny.
Why on Earth would we have sex?
I’m quite aware of the way humans usually reproduce, which is messy, unsanitary, and based on living next to you for three years, involves loud and unnecessary appeals to a deity.

Yes, exactly. Consequently, if Amy and I choose to bring new life into this world, it will be accomplished clinically, with fertility experts in a lab with petri dishes. Which reminds me, you have broad hips and a certain corn-fed vigour. Is your womb available for rental?
You mean dating?
I can’t date Amy.
She’s not my girlfriend.
Oh. I hadn’t considered that. I suppose she will have to have access to our progeny. And you don’t think I can achieve the required intimacy via text messaging?
Huh. It would appear as if the phone companies have been lying to me.
(Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.
I know. I can see the shadow of your feet under the door.
If you’re looking for an example of a waste of time, I would refer you to the conversation we’re having right now.
I’ve decided to take your advice and have arranged to go on a date with Amy Farrah Fowler.
Wait. You have to drive me.
You know I don’t drive.
I did. He said, and I quote, ask Penny, it was her cockamamie idea.
Actually, I’m paraphrasing. Having been raised in a Christian household, I’m uncomfortable with the language he used. And to be honest, I’m not entirely comfortable with cockamamie.
Now.
Hurry. We’re going to be late.
I’m sorry. Do you have other plans?
So this conversation is as pointless as your door-knocking soliloquy?
Thank you for driving me.
I wish you weren’t wearing flip-flops. It’s dangerous to drive in flip-flops.
Sorry. I just don’t want to be yet another flip-flop fatality.
Given your community college education, I encourage you to ask me as many as possible.
That depends. Does square-dancing with my sister at a Teens for Jesus Fourth of July Hoedown count as a date?
Then, this is my first date.
I have a master’s degree and two doctorates. The things I should know, I do know.
If you know so much, how come I have a date tonight and you have nothing better to do than drive me to it?
Don’t bother. I’ve wasted many an hour tilting at that particular windmill.
Oh, no, I wouldn’t care for that. Amy?
No.
All right. It was hell.
I’m sorry, how is this better than uncomfortable silence?
Muggles.
Big night? The winter solstice is a big night. It’s over 14 hours in Southern California.
Thank you.
Apparently, a semi-incestuous Teens for Jesus Fourth of July Hoedown didn’t count.
Your characterization of approximately 171 different men as a few.

Simple extrapolation. In the three years that I’ve known you, you were single for two. During that time, I saw 17 different suitors. If we work backwards, correcting for observation bias and postulate an initial dating age of 15…
I’m sorry. 16?
My mistake. Now, assuming the left side of a bell curve peaking around the present, that would bring the total up to 193 men. Plus or minus eight men.
Although that number would be fairly easy to calculate.

Based on the number of awkward encounters I’ve had with strange men leaving her apartment in the morning, plus the number of times she’s returned home wearing the same clothes she wore the night before…
So we multiply 193, minus 21 men before the loss of virginity, so 172 times 0.18 gives us 30.96 sexual partners. Let’s round that up to 31.
This is an interesting topic. How many sexual encounters have you had?
I should think so.
You were right. This was a very productive evening. I saw a whole new side of Amy Farrah Fowler tonight.

I’ll be happy to check the math, but numbers don’t lie, Penny. In any event, now that Amy and I have spent quality time together, I feel much more confident proceeding to the next stage of our relationship.
Using in vitro fertilization and a surrogate uterus to gift humanity with our progeny.
In these uncertain times, doesn’t humanity deserve a gift?
That’s no threat. My mother’s always wanted a grandchild.
Curses.
Well, it’s not that late. You could still go out and look for number 32. Good night.
I’ve decided not to procreate.
Penny (arriving): Hey. Is the food here? Ooh. What’s that?
Penny: Ah, cool.
Oh, does that come up much on the space station?
All right. Pass the soy sauce.
Oh, it’s not bad. Kind of hungry.
Really? They’re going to make a robot that spits on your hamburger?
Oh ha-ha, oh. That’s amazing.
Does NASA know you’re using that thing as a napkin holder?
You stole it?
Who’s Amy?
Sheldon has a girlfriend?
How long has this been going on?
Are you telling me, for the past four months I have been asking you what’s new and you never thought to go with Sheldon has a girlfriend?
Ah, du-du-du-du-du. How did they meet?
Oh, my God! Sheldon and Amy.
Okay, well, what do you communicate about?
Okay, I have a question.
You don’t even like people touching you. How are you going to have sex?
Oh, honey, did your mom not have the talk with you? You know, when your private parts started growing?
Oh, God.
Look, Sheldon, before you race off to the fertility clinic, you might want to think about, uh gee, I don’t know, maybe actually spending some time with her.
Yeah.
Why not?
Okay, look, don’t think of it as dating a girlfriend. Think of it as, uh, getting to know the future mother of your child.
Probably not.
You do realize I stand on the other side of the door waiting for you to finish knocking three times.
Yeah, my point is it’s a waste of time.
What do you want?
Oh, that’s great. Have fun.
What?
Well, go ask Leonard.
Leonard said cockamamie?
Okay, fine. When’s the date?
Now?
Sheldon, did it ever occur to you that I might have other plans?
Well, no, not per se, but…
Let me get my cockamamie keys.
You’re welcome.
Sheldon.
Can I ask you a question?
Yeah. Well, my question is, and I’m pretty sure I know the answer, is this your first date?
No.
Okay. Well, then, there’s a couple of things you should probably know.
My point is, I know more about dating than you, and if you were as smart as you think you are, you would listen to me.
Fair point.
So, um, Amy, Sheldon tells me you’re a neuro something-or-other.
Yeah, it’s okay.
Um, what is that scent you’re wearing? It smells great.
Ah. Well, your hair looks very nice.
No, no, I was just giving you a compliment.
Guys, how ’bout some music?
Okay. Uncomfortable silence it is. Hey, Sheldon, have you told Amy what it was like for you growing up in Texas?
Well, why don’t you tell her?
Any follow up, Amy?
I myself grew up in Nebraska. Small town outside of Omaha. You know, nice place, mostly family farms, a few meth labs.
I don’t know. I was just trying something.
Hey, here’s another possible topic of conversation. This is a big night for Sheldon. Right, Sheldon?
No, no. My point is, uh, tonight is Sheldon’s first official date. Discuss.
So, um, Amy, what about you? Do you date much?
Uh, yeah, I wouldn’t say many. A few. (Sheldon laugh’s strangely). What’s (imitates Sheldon’s laugh)
What? Where did you get 171 men?
Whoa, wait, wait, wait. I did not start dating at 15.
No.
Oh.
Okay, Sheldon, I think you’ve made your point.
Okay, Sheldon, you are so wrong. That is not even close to the real number. I’m gonna need a drink over here.
No! No! No. Let’s just all finish our dinners, okay?
I did not have sex with 31 guys.
And that is?
You’re still on that?
Okay, you know what? I’m gonna come at this in a whole new way. Sheldon, if you try to make a baby with Amy in a petri dish, I’m gonna tell your mother on you.
Really? Your deeply religious born-again Christian mother wants a test-tube grandbaby born out of wedlock?
If I’d thought of that in the first place, I could’ve saved myself this whole night.
Sheldon (phone gives text alert): Excuse me. Oh. Amy’s at the dry cleaners, and she’s made a very amusing pun. “I don’t care for perchloroethylene, and I don’t like glycol ether.” Get it? She doesn’t like glycol ether. Sounds like either. (Taps in reply) L-O-L.
Penny (squeals): Shamy. I am so digging the Shamy.
Mrs Wolowitz (off): Howard, I made cookies for you and your little friends!
I’ll bring them up with some Hawaiian Punch!
Why not?! Are you ashamed of your mother?!
Leonard (phone rings): Hold that thought. Hey, Howard, what’s going on? What? Hold on, Howard, Howard, slow down. The robot hand is stuck on your what? (To Raj) You’re not going to believe this.
Amy: Neurobiologist. Your check engine light is on.
Dandruff shampoo. I have dry scalp.
Hmm. Would have been more flattered if you were a homosexual.

Once a year. It’s a deal I made with my mother in exchange for her silence on the matter, as well as the occasional use of her George Foreman Grill that seals in the flavour without the fat. How about you, Penny? Do you go on many dates?
Remarkable. Did you have sexual intercourse with all of these men?
This is very interesting. Cultural perceptions are subjective. Penny, to your mind, are you a slut?
Does volunteering for a scientific experiment in which orgasm was achieved by electronically stimulating the pleasure centres of the brain count?
Nurse: My, my, my. What do we have here?
Yeah, we get that a lot. What is this?
Where’s the rest of the robot?
All right, all right. Hang on, stay calm. (Over PA system)  I need an orderly with a wheelchair. I got a robot hand grasping a man’s penis out here.
I’m sorry, we don’t have a code for robot hand grasping a man’s penis. Why is it hooked up to a computer?
Did you try turning it off and back on again?
